p: Other methods are possible, for example cluster-based inference of the reproduction number (see e.g. [55], [56]) is a promising approach. In the current context, Kernéis et al. [20] provided detailed information on prevalence and risk factors of Lassa ( e.g. history of collecting, cutting and eating rats) stratified by age. In addition, the age distribution from KGH is also available. These data could be combined together to build a matrix of transmission rates among age-groups (as done in [55], [56]) and between rodents and each age-group with values based on the findings of Kernéis et al. [20].
